characters: A BATON TWIRLING IN THE AIR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A splitВ—level house on a slight grade of lawn. A red Hon the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here on the sofa bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to record how much we love each other. Sitting beside me is the cutest majorette in the history of the world. And she would Like to say something. A real estate agent, a WOMAN, carries a "For Sale" sign t the center of the lawn and begins driving it in with a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Peggy. Say what we rehearsed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I'm too embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING VIEW, revealing the empty house. We HEAR the RECOR LOUDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you love me don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Come on Charlie, turn it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And nothing will ever change that. Charlie starts giggling. We HEAR fumbling and tickling. CLOSE VIEW INTO THE KITCHEN - First we see a woman's hand the floor. It is partially covered with flour. MOVING VIEW reveals PEGGY BODELL, in her early 40's, fain from heartbreak while baking a cake. Flour is scattered o the floor. She recovers from her faint. Confused, she steadies herself and brushes the flour from her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy's son, SCOTT, 16, is playing an old reel to reel ta recorder. There are stacks of boxes filled with personal things and records. His sister, BETH, 23, is packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, have they changed. Who gets it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, just put it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, gotta go. Here's a little makeВ—out music. A record starts: "You Belong to Me" by the Duprees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE BODELL, early 40's, singing the same song. He can hit a high note, turns off the water and steps out of the shower. JANET, his young, buxom girlfriend is in the bedr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit, I just can't hit those high notes anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Charlie, if you're serious about this, I know a great vocal coach. Charlie's perplexed reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Crazy Charlie's Discount Appliances" truck has parked in front of the house. WORKMEN are loading boxes of records, tapes, etc. Charlie pulls up, waves to workmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy is loading the oddВ—shaped cakes into boxes. We not grandfather clock tolling nine.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW IN HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Beth meets her father at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Dad, can I have 100 dollars for a brake job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I hear 70 dollars? What do you  need 50 dollars for? How's your Mom? Peggy comes out of the kitchen. Charlie has stopped conspicuously at the threshold. A workman comes from behi Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, watch the clock. Peggy looks outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janet is seated in Charlie's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something pathetic parked in front of my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come off it, Peggy. And what do you mean your house? This is my house. I paid for it, I'm still paying for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still waiting for the mortgage check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mailed it to you on Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, today's Saturday and it's still not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Peggy. Take it easy. I'm not used to that stuff. You always did the bills. Blame the damn post office. A workman approaches carrying an old mono record player: black and white, a real fifties artifact. For a moment th mutual resentment melts, as they look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That stays. The workman looks to Charlie for approval. Charlie nods. workman shrugs, and heads back to the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a Tab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't buy them anymore. You were the only one who drank them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy leads the way. At the far end, she flips a light sw that turns on a wall sculpture of lava lamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want them? They're going to make a big comeback any minute. Mark my words, these lamps are going to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Put Scott through college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll think of a way to sell, them. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day. Peggy opens a box filled with records. She closes it and moves to another. Charlie checks the contents of another on the other side of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you taking Janet to the reunion tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going. Scott calls from the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right there. I'll go through the rest of this stuff next weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye sweetheart. Peggy and Charlie look at each other as Scott leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with real, regret)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought it would go this far. Charlie exits. Peggy looks around. She slaps the flap of box down, to close it, but it jumps back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Beth carry the cake boxes into the car  A NEIGH trimming the hedge watches them lasciviously. Peggy and Beth drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy's car rounds a corner into the business section of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy pulls up to the front door of The Lovin' Oven, her shop. Bags of bread and rolls lean against the door. Beth jumps out and opens the door of the shop. Peggy stacks th boxes in Beth's arms and opens the door for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the pastries aren't here by nine thirty, call Monica and threaten her life. Peggy gets into the car, and blows a kiss to Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back by noon. Peggy drives off as MONICA drives up. She exits her car a begins to unpack cake boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Monica. You just missed Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. My Bobo's back in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT:        Sign: KRISTIN'S COIFFURES Peggy exits with a fifties flip. From a distance she look like a fifties teenager. She nervously looks at her reflection. Maybe this was a mistake. Too late now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy is driving. On her car radio, we HEAR a local PHONE TALK SHOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Dolores Dodge. We're taking calls today on surrogate mothers. Wombs for rent. I want to know how you feel..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Dolores. Peggy switches stations until she finds the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy stops for a red light. Her eye is caught by a Merce stopped next to her. Behind the wheel is a striking woman her age, CAROL HEATH. They stare curiously for a beat, th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue! They pull over to the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exiting the cars, they hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you in years. In all that time, haven't you at least tried another hair style? Peggy tries to laugh off her embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1 just did it for the reunion. I thought it would be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're probably the only one who could carry it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Carol enter as Beth finishes up with a customer Peggy walks behind the counter as the customer exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you? You said you'd be back at twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my old friend Carol.. I told you about her. Beth and Carol exchange hellos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: r was worried about you  You didn't even call. You're always on my case if I don't call..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like my hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks great. Don't change the subject. You know how busy Saturdays are. And I can't do the icing. I always mess up the roses. You're not being very responsible. Peggy takes over the work of decorating the large pennant shaped cake in silver icing: 25th Reunion В— Buchanan Hig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the mother around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A television studio set made up of platforms covered with black cloth. Placed around the platforms on different lev are projection TVs, regular TVs, microwave ovens and othe expensive, futuristic appliances. Charlie sits at one of (or a table) as a CHINESE WAITER rushes in and puts a tra fortune cookies down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here Charlie, extra fortune cookies. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Charlie grabs a cookie and puts it on the table in front him, smashing it with his fist. He picks up and reads the fortune:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (manic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next week you'll be selling Sanyo remote control VCRs for three hundred and ninetyВ—nine dollars? Oh no! (sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy Charlie... He grabs and smashes another fortune cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll give away Mitsubishi giant screen TVs for twelve hundred and ninetyВ—five dollars! Oh no! I'll go broke! (sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy Charlie... He grabs and smashes another cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't be undersold on stereos, videos, microwaves or blenders! (sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy Charlie, Crazy Charlie, I'm not breaking cookies, I'm smashing prices. (rolling his eyes like

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabian) Crazy Charlie, he insane. The waiter hits a big gong. Beth laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn that off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK from the TV into Peggy's bedroom. Beth up from the bed and turns off the TV. Peggy enters from t adjoining bathroom, wearing a robe, and bobby socks with saddle shoes. She picks up a gold Locket from the dresser and puts it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you going to stop being so mad at Dad? How do you think that makes me feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a lot of unresolved feelings about him. I don't trust him. Besides, I hate those commercials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I asked. We don't have time for another heartВ—toВ— heart. Here, try on the dress. Peggy tries on the fifties dress lying on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I want you and Scott to understand. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he loves Janet? Maybe he's smashed too many fortune cookies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Mom. Give him a break. He's missing the reunion because of you. You know he wants to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'd both have a miserable time. What do you think? She looks exactly like a sixties teenager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you're a hip chick. You look like you stepped right out of Life magazine. Any time you want to borrow it again, just ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Borrow?! This was my dress. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's a mistake. What if I'm the only one? I don't even want to go. Everybody's just going to say... (imitating commercial)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.. Where's Crazy Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, lots of people are separated and divorced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not from the guy with the lowest prices in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couples are walking up the stairs into the school. Peggy Beth are at the bottom of the stairs, staring at the bann hung across the entrance.. It reads: WELCOME CLASS OF '60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel ridiculous. Maybe I should go home and change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you so nervous? What is the matter with you today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Reunions do funny things to people. At that moment they're joined by MADDY.(Madeline) and ART NAGLE, coming up behind them. A typical polyester couple. Hellos all around and hugs. Arthur puts his arms around B and Peggy and leads them up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two look like that soap commercial. Which one's the daughter and which one's the mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took this seriously. You're a real blast from the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Beth's idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I had the nerve. And the figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always were a crazy little gal, Peg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, please don't call me Peg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large table in the lobby holds plastic nametags. A sign reads: LADIES IF YOU CAN'T FIND TOUR TAG, LOOK UNDER YOUR MAIDEN NAME. Several people are bending over the table looking for their tags. A HOSTESS is sitting behind the table. Peggy, Beth, Maddy and Arthur enter. Hellos all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth's boyfriend is playing in the band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must run in the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your mother both seem to fall for musicians. Maddy and Arthur laugh. Peggy is not amused. The hostess hands them their name tags and turns to welcome new arriv As they proceed down the hallway, Peggy SEES a distinguis man enter, RICHARD NORVIK. With him is his pregnant wife SHARON. Richard smiles at Peggy. She can't place him. Peg turns back to her group and continues down the hall. The fifties MUSIC GETS LOUDER AND LOUDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gym is packed with people dancing, chatting, greeting lost friends. A bar is set up at one end. On the walls ar black and white blowВ—ups of the 1960 yearbook. On a tabl a buffet and Peggy' s cake. The BAND is PLAYING and SINGI old rock and roll songs. Couples slow dance, jive and str Peggy, Beth, Maddy and Arthur enter. Beth leaves the grou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, there's Terry and Leon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy, would you find a table? We'll see you in a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. They walk away into the crowd, leaving Peggy alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CL0SE VIEW В— A photo of the majorettes. Peggy is in the middle, twirling her baton. Her reverie is interrupted by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Peggy Sue Kelcher?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was once. Richard!? Richard Norvik? I didn't recognize you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look exactly the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just did it for tonight. I don't normally dress like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's adorable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry.. Peggy Sue Kelcher, my wife Sharon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Nice to meet you. Please call me Peggy. I'm Peggy Bodell now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Charlie? I was in town about a year ago and caught one of his commercials. Really made me laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not here. We're getting divorced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee. I'm sorry to hear that. NEW VIEW В— A large, beefy HAND is THRUST INTO FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Norvik. CAMERA PULLS BACK TO INCLUDE DOUG SNELL, a paunchy, overbearing man, shaking Richard's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or, uhh, Richard?  David Snell, Merrill Lynch.  I read about the Cordex deal in Business Week. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Peggy. How are you? How's Char1ie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEWS ON Carol and Walter. They play a standoffish game, noticing the other, but pretending not to. We HEAR and SEE bits of conversations:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gleeful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe how she let herself go. She was so beautiful in high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's got a gold Rolex. I had this one specially made in platinum. Richard is standing with three men. They hang on his ever word. Beside them, a very DRUNK MAN overhears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...fifth generation core capacities are going to cause another shakeВ—out in the smaller companies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Richard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your damn computers put me out of business. You're a billionaire, and I'm a goddamn failure. Another man gently restrains the drunk and leads him away Richard is shaken.

dialogues.speaker: NEW VIEW
dialogues.text: Carol and Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the singles scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how you do it. I've never even dated anybody but Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just have to remember... men are like houses and trade upwards... I thought you had a pretty good marriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did for a long time. We just got married too young, and ended up blaming each other for missing out on things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he started having affairs, and you got depressed. Peggy nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have left here years ago, like I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the place. I don't buy that. (melodramatic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trapped in the same town forever. The price she would pay for her teenage lust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you got knocked up, my mother didn't want me to talk to you. She thought it was contagious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's not so bad. I have two wonderful kids, my own business. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, knowing what I know now, if I had the chance to do it all over again, I'd sure do things a lot differently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't we all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLORES DODGE is about to interview Maddy and Arthur; she turns on the tape machine and holds up the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madeline Hutton and Arthur Nagle were high school sweethearts. Married right after graduation, they're still together. In this day and age, that's remarkable... Maddy, Arthur, how does it feel to have missed the sexual revolution?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incensed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of question is that? It has nothing to do with the reunion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully В— into mike)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you asked, Dolores. Four years ago Maddy and I found Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spiritual renewal.. That's what reunions are all about. Familiar faces, forgotten memories, ancient dance steps and music...the great time machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS the gym and FINDS: Carol dancing with WALTER GETZ, slim, handsome, with a bi toothy grin. Carol's old high school boyfriend, he's now dentist and a fabulous dancer. They make a great team. Couples dancing around them react appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never could keep up with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a quick tap step)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just call me Walter the dancing dentist. Taps and caps. My specialty.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY'S TABLE.
dialogues.text: Peggy sits with Richard, Sharon, and two other couples, T and LISA and LEON and SANDY. A hand gently touches Peggy on the shoulder. Peggy turns around and sees ROSALIE TESTA, a small woman with close cropped hair. She's in a wheelchair. She wears a plastic badge: REUNION COMMITTEE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember that dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosalie Testa! 'HELLOS' all, around. Peggy helps Rosalie position her wheelchair at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember when you got that locket, too. You were so excited I think you showed it to the whole school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have an incredible memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful. Does it open?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. These are my children. But they're not babies anymore.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKET
dialogues.text: Inside are photos of Beth and Scott as babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you got married when you were three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores interviewing Walter and Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol Pritchard Heath and Walter Getz were high school steadies who went their separate ways. After twenty years and four divorces between them, they meet again В— Walter a successful dentist, Carol a mature career woman. Carol, why did you really come back for this reunion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curiosity mostly. I heard you finally found a man of your own. Too bad he's married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cracking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Cat fight! Purse war!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores walks resolutely towards their table. Maddy and. Arthur leave the table as Dolores approaches, putting her tape machine on the table. She ignores everyo focusing on Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello everyone. Richard Norvik? I'm Dolores Dodge with KARP Radio. Could I have a minute of your time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I remember you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAND is PLAYING and SINGING the SONG "GOOD OLD ROCK A ROLL." Peggy and Sharon walk through the gym looking at t photo blowups on the wall. Peggy is stopped and hugged by several people. Maddy and Arthur are dancing. Despite the frantic beat, they are slow dancing. Seth is hanging arou the stage, bringing a drink to the guitar player. Walter dancing with Rosalie in her wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns out I love business. Every morning I wake up, thank God I'm alive, and say Who am I gonna screw today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's play "Rate the Moment". I give tonight an eightyВ—seven. Better than sex, not as good as racquetball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores has left. Walter lays out lines of cocaine on the back of the clipboard, as Carol watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best thing about being a dentist. Pure pharmaceutical grade. A couple of lines of this, I can drill my own teeth... (looks at her for a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moment) Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his wife)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe would have enjoyed this. God, I still miss him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Carol)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy was a mess right after they separated, but I think she's coming out of it... It seems to be pretty friendly now..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes it's easier when you hate them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't remember. Did I make it with you in high school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't it feel like it was yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Youth is like an amputated leg. Long after it's gone, you still feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife's a cow, my son has shit for brains, and my daughter's in India with Mother Teresa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband's a pig. But my son's in social work and my daughter, God bless her, is in India with Mother Teresa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the fitness generation, we've sure got a lot of porkers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember anything about the seventies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breaking up was horrible. I said we had a very special attachment, he said, so does a Hoover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I came back. I hated high school. The group around him all answer "So did I" or "Me too."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I enjoyed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy (loose, holding a drink) and Sharon stand in front PHOTO of the 1960 Cross Country Team. VIEW ON PHOTO - off to one side stands MICHAEL FITZSIMMON His hair is longer, his gaze intense and nonВ—smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the one with the hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael Fitzsimmons. I had such a crush on him. Carol and Maddy join them, still panting from dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Peggy. God, that Walter Getz        can still dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your first boyfriend. What do you think? Any sparks left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows. Remember... (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever Walter wants...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Getz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon Norvik this is Carol Heath, and Maddy Nagle. My oldest and dearest friends. Sharon's married to Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky lady. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the photo)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael Fitzsimmons! Is he here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I asked Rosalie. She couldn't track him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have been quite a guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the only one in high school I wished I'd gone to bed with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, besides Charlie, of course. We HOLD on the photo of Michael and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAND is PLAYING AND SINGING the SONG, "JUST BECAUSE." Couples axe slow dancing. Dolores is still interviewing Richard. Peggy, Sharon and Carol walk back to their table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy, would you please rescue Richard? Ask him to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we through Dolores? Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... Richard stands and helps Sharon to a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sharon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You go ahead. Peggy and Richard head onto the crowded floor, and begin dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only time people like Dolores used to pay any attention to me was to laugh at me or insult me. That guy, Doug Snell, who shook my hand when we walked in, he used to call me a fourВ—eyed worm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you showed them. You're rich and famous and successful. And you have a beautiful wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were always friendly to me. I appreciated that. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, this used to be a fantasy of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dancing with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a sweet man, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess part of us never really leaves high school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I never told anybody this, but I always had a feeling that when you die, before you go to heaven, you get a chance to fly around high school for a while. CAMERA PULLS BACK SLOWLY as Peggy and Richard become part the sea of dancers, all Lost in nostalgic reverie.

dialogues.speaker: BY DOOR
dialogues.text: Charlie enters and stands by the door. He's tentative, looking around for his friends. Almost immediately he is joined by Arthur, Walter, Terry and Leon. They shake hand glad to see each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes the life of the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you couldn't stay away. Everyone's happy to see Charlie. His eyes meet Peggy's he gives her a tentative, sheepish wave. Terry looks at the band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, they could've at least asked us to sing. We'd refuse, of course, but they could've asked us.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: Looking at Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: BY STAGE
dialogues.text: Arthur walks onstage, placing a hatbox on the amplifier. a ChamberВ—ofВ—Commerce type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into microphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Can I have your attention, please. The BUZZ in the room DIMS, Peggy and Richard head back to their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's getting kind of late, and some of you have a long drive home, so the reunion committee decided it was time for the moment you've all been waiting for. You don't know what you've been waiting for because we didn't tell you, but the committee has selected a King and Queen. Now don't worry, I took care of it so the band's gonna keep playing for at least another hour, and my old pal Judge Crystal said that the bar can stay open as long as we want. Everyone applauds.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON PEGGY AND CHARLIE
dialogues.text: At opposite ends of the reunion, but aware of each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And while you're at it, let's have a nice big hand for the Little Lady that did such a great job supervising all the decorations, Rosalie Testa. More applause. VIEW on Rosalie in her wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now back to business. The members of the committee have given this a lot of thought and decided on the two people who best represent the spirit of Buchanan High's Class of '60. The king is someone who, in more ways than one, has come a long, long way since he left here.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY'S TABLE
dialogues.text: They all look to Richard, knowing he's the obvious choice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're proud to welcome him back, Richard Norvik! Come on up here, King Richard! The band PLAYS a FANFARE and DRUM ROLL. Richard gets up, walks to the stage as everyone APPLAUDS. The band PLAYS a chorus of "Get a Job."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kidding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I demand a recount. (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: VIEW ON STAGE
dialogues.text: Arthur places the gold cardboard crown on Richard's head they shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharon and I thank you all for making us feel so welcome. It's good to be back. MORE APPLAUSE as Richard steps back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every king deserves a queen. Now, we had a Lot at worthwhile candidates. And I don't want any of you ladies to feel left out, 'cause you're all beautiful. But when we sent out the invitations, we didn't mention anything about this being a costume party. Peggy's embarrassed reaction, realizing everyone's lookin her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should have, 'cause just looking at her brings it all back for us. Ladies and gentlemen, I give you our queen, Peggy Sue Kelcher Bodell. Come on up here, Peggy Sue. The band begins the song PEGGY SUE. Peggy looks pained. S doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're waiting. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (close to tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. It's all too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. You can do it. Charlie and Beth stand together: Beth is worried about Pe CAMERA TRACKS Peggy as she haltingly makes her way to the stage. As she does, she notices another blow-up on the wa Peggy and Charlie, as King and Queen of the 1960 prom. Ar gives the crown to Richard who places it on Peggy's head. kisses her cheek and stands back, beaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike, overwhelmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.. Thank you very much. The lights dim, leaving Peggy in the spotlight. Continued APPLAUSE as the singer steps up to his mike and begins to SING the song PEGGY SUE.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY ON STAGE
dialogues.text: People starting to clap and sing along. Carol and Carol's POV: a blowВ—up on the wall of Carol in the senior play. Walter and. Walter's POV: a photo of Walter on the basket team. People leaving their tables, surging towards the st drawn by the music. Maddy and Maddy's POV: a photo of Mad and friends mugging for the camera in the cafeteria. Char talking to Carol. Peggy begins to cry softly. The images begin to melt together, pulsing to the music. Peggy is the focus of everyone's nostalgia. A wave of time washes over them. She remains onstage, looking past the crowd to the photo her and Charlie. Peggy onstage, eyes closed, swaying to the music. Walter Carol join hands, walking towards the stage. Rosalie in h wheelchair, doing the hand jive, crying. The entire crowd swaying to the music, looking to Peggy, repeating the chorus over and over. Beth notices her mother's state of emotion. Peggy collaps onstage. We hear SHOUTS and SCREAMS. Richard, Arthur and several others crowd over Peggy. Beth rushes to the stage reaching out to her mother. Charlie too. MUSIC STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: INTO PEGGY'S ARM
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to INCLUDE Peggy lying on a cot. She we the same dress she had on at the reunion. She's terrified We NEAR a smattering of background noises: NAMES are CALL NURSES helping, etc. Looking up she sees: The IV. The NURSE taking the IV out of her arm, and placing a via blood on a tray with several others. Peggy sits up slowly dazed and frightened. She looks at the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like your Twinkie now? Peggy takes the Twinkie, staring at it blankly. Looking around she SEES students giving blood to the Red Cross. Several have tubes in their arms. Nurses attend to them. Carol sits up drinking a cup of juice, waving weakly at Peggy. Maddy, now a brunette, slowly rolls down her sleev Arthur, Dolores, Walter and several others from the reuni Everyone is younger but instantly recognizable.. Charlie walks over to Peggy. He grins at her, revealing w vampire fangs in his mouth, hair Brylcreemed to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I vant to suck your blood. I also vant to suck your Twinkie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie! Am I dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You are the undead. You will live forever if you give me your Twinkie. (normal voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's have it. You hate them anyway. Mechanically, Peggy hands over the Twinkie. Charlie bends over to nuzzle her neck. The nurse's hand COMES INTO FRAM and grabs Charlie by the scruff of the neck, pulling him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young man, stop that. The SCHOOL BELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! I just made a deposit in your blood bank. Now I want to make a withdrawal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's time for your next class -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm changing banks! Charlie walks away towards Walter and Arthur. Peggy gazes after him, his body blocking her view of a portion of a banner hung on the wall. It reads: "Support the Buchanan Blood Drive..." As Charlie exits, the final words come in view: "Spring 1960." Peggy gasps. She begins to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lie back down and take a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You passed out for a moment. Nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did I get here? Maddy and Carol approach, carrying their books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you let your friends help you? (to Maddy and Carol)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take her into the washroom and splash some cold water on her face. That should perk her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma' am. They help Peggy up and lead her across the gym.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls enter. Carol immediately lights up a cigarette. Peggy crosses to the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peggy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna smoke? That's the worst thing for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. I gave them up years ago. Maddy and Carol react as Peggy takes a closer look at her and the girls' reflections. She places a hand to her thro noticing the locket is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were taking you back to the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maddy, what did you do to your hair? Maddy looks in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maddy and Carol are waiting. Peggy exits the office, clutching a note which she hands blankly to Maddy. They w towards the exit, Peggy glued to the wall for support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to take you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. I'm sure I'll remember the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls walk outside. Peggy looks around at the old car the parking lot. The most noticeable В— a blue Chevrolet Impala convertible. Peggy stares at it for a beat, shiver with recognition, as she follows Carol and Maddy to a 195 Ford. Maddy helps Peggy into the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol drives and chats with Maddy, while in the back seat Peggy looks out at the world as it she were on a ride at Disneyland. She says things like "That's not here anymore

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls up to the curb. Peggy gets out of the car. Maddy hands her the note and her books; she twirls her fi next to her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you Later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Let's stay in touch. Peggy walks up to the door, a sleepwalker in suspended animation. She waits a beat and knocks softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy. (shuddering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in. It's open. Peggy slowly opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy enters and looks down the hallway into the kitchen. EVELYN KELCHER is a lovely woman in her midВ—forties. She turns around from the sink and approaches Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helplessly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse called and said you'd be coming home. Peggy stares blankly at her for a beat, then holds up the note, as she moves towards her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm excused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go lie down for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom! Peggy embraces her mother, holding on for dear life, inha her scent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chanel Number Five. That always reminds me of home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, dear. You're home now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm home now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy enters warily, looking around, a fifties museum of teenage artifacts. She walks around the room gently touch her old belongings including the record player from openi scene. She looks in the mirror to make sure she's still there. Suddenly, she turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm alone now. Is anyone here? She opens the closet door expectantly, then closes it sha her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. This is crazy. Is somebody going to tell me what's going on? Why me? What happened? You don't have to show up. I don't have to see you. Just send me a sign. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot. 1 guess I'm on my own. NANCY, Peggy's twelveВ—yearВ—old sister, peeks in the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy! Come here. Nancy tentatively approaches. Peggy hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just happy to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! Mom said you were sick. You're never happy to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about that. I really want us to be closer. I have enough unresolved relationships in my... life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teenagers are weird. And you're the weirdest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do something together.. Do you want to play Monopoly? Or Careers... Clue... Snakes and Ladders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, what do you want? What dumb favor do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a small black and white TV, Dick Clark introduces a spotlight dance. Peggy and Nancy are sitting on the sofa, watching. Nancy is eating small candies, like M&M's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's unbelievable. The man never ages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at Kenny Rossi. Isn't he dreamy? I wish he'd break up with Arlene. She thinks she's so great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't eat the red ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? They're my favorite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're bad for you. They cause...red lips. (red dye *2) Nancy react, as Peggy stands. CAMERA TRACKS HER to the de

dialogues.speaker: DEN
dialogues.text: Peggy opens the liquor cabinet and takes out a bottle of Scotch and a glass, noticing the family photos on the wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't hurt. I'm already dead. She belts down several drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue! Hurry up. Fabian! Peggy steadies herself as CAMERA TRACKS her back into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Peggy collapses on the naugahyde recliner. Unexpectedly, leans back, shooting Peggy's legs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the kitchen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put your laundry on your beds. Don't forget to put it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meatloaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeech, not again. Peggy leans forward in the recliner eating the candies. Bemused, she looks at Nancy watching TV and into the kitc where her mother is slapping together meatloaf.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: JACK KELCHER Peggy's father, enters the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls? Evelyn? Who left this thing outside? He turns and heads back outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? Mrs. Kelcher and Nancy follow him outside. Peggy staggers the front door and leans against the door jamb looking ou the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family admires a new red and white Edsel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disturbed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like wow! Wait till I tell Diane. She's always bragging about her father's Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Daddy. You were always doing things like that. (cracking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny! That's really funny. She staggers over to the car and falls against it laughin Mr. Kelcher crosses to her and catches a whiff of her bre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young lady, you're drunk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little. I've had a tough day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see the humor in this. Go to your room immediately. You're grounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tipsy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grounded? Ha! The story of my life. I don't wanna go to my room. I wanna import Japanese cars. I wanna go to Liverpool and discover the Beatles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, take it easy. She gave blood at school today. Maybe she's just a little lightВ—headed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not giving blood. This is drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, I never knew you had a sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn, put her to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy lies in bed, her mother tucking her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My little baby. Don't try to grow up so fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Mom, I forgot you were ever so young.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: She hears her mother walk down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new car. We can't afford a new car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, it's just a seasonal slump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have four seasons, you have four slumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy emerges from the bathroom wearing a towel.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW FROM BACK
dialogues.text: At a full length mirror she drops the towel and happily appraises her eighteen year old body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get physical!... Let's get metaphysical! Nancy comes in dressed for school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. Nancy goes to Peggy's closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I borrow this sweater?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but take good care of it.        I'm saving it for my daughter.. She loves this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kelcher and Nancy sit at the table eating breakfast. Kelcher stands at the sink scraping toast. Peggy bounces hair in her adult, natural look. "GOOD MORNINGS" all arou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your hair? You have such a pretty face. Why are you always trying to cover it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I forgot. Mrs. Kelcher takes an elastic band from around the faucet hands it to Peggy as she sits at the table. Peggy makes a ponytail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking pretty chipper this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still here, aren't I? I may as well enjoy myself. I'm going to go to school today. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, I want to apologize for yesterday. The car is a classic. Use it in the best of health.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.. I accept your apology with the hope that what went on yesterday will never happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so young, this is not the time to start acquiring bad habits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, is there any coffee left? Mrs. Kelcher begins to pour the coffee, then pulls back, spilling some on Mr. Kelcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you start drinking coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.        Ah...recently. All the kids drink it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If all the kids jumped off a bridge, would you do that too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm way ahead of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass the toast, please. Peggy passes Nancy the toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the butter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you two are wonderful parents. I'm really going to try to behave myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at least you stopped calling me DaddyВ—O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (correcting him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DADDYВ—o.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, sit down for a minute. This is so nice, all of us being together again like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I tell Diane that Peggy Sue got drunk or is that a deep family secret? (silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does Diane like her braces?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hates them. Nobody likes braces. Thy just call you junkyard face and Miss Metal Mouth. I gotta go. Nancy jumps up, grabbing her lunch on the counter, as she exits. "GOODВ—BYES' all around. We HEAR a HORN HONKING ou В—В— a fiveВ—note musical phrase В—В— BEВ—BOPВ—AВ—LUВ—BOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Charlie. How am I going to handle him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Did you two  have a fight?.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house payments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy exits the house wincing at the sight of Charlie's c the blue Impala she'd seen the day before. Charlie sits, arm on the wheel, the other over the back of the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty strange. Peggy hesitates, unsure how to handle her accumulated ambivalence towards Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. Get in. I can take care of that. Peggy warily gets in. Charlie leans over to kiss her, but pushes him away. No dice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, Charlie. I've got a headache. Get used to the word. Roll it around your tongue for a years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I can take a hint. You look great today. Charlie starts the car, burns rubber and peels out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drive like a maniac!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call this the staccato. (does tricks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I'm glad you were sick, but I had a chance to do some thinking last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know. About what we said on Tuesday. It makes a lot of sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Refresh my memory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you forget? We talk about seeing other people and you forget?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I blocked it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can understand that.. But please don't start crying again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's car pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not going to be forever. I figure three years is long enough. I can see it the music pans out. (more tentative)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And right after graduation we should start seeing other people. Kind of comparison shop before we settle down and get married. Know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we got the prom coming up, all these parties. We shouldn't upset our parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll learn to live with it. Peggy exits the car and heads towards the school. Charlie sits, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are surrounded by friends as they head into school. the door Walter and Leon are having a contest, hoisting themselves onto the sign pole, trying to get their bodies parallel to the ground. A crowd urges them on. We SEE tap the bottom of Walter's shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy stands bewildered in the hallway. Charlie walks bac takes her by the hand and leads her to a locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're more shook up than you want to admit. You'll get used to it, we'll still see each other 2, 3 times a week. Charlie opens the locker. Peggy watches carefully, memori tho combination. He takes out a few books as Peggy notice her schedule on the locker door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to drive you home later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (growling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I?!! Why I oughta... Unaccountably, this cracks Charlie up. He walks away laughing. Peggy looks completely puzzled. She is surround by a sea of people, who say hello. She can't remember the names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE Peggy, Maddy, Dolores, Arthur and Carol, singing M COUNTRY TIS OF THEE. They all mumble, except for Peggy wh delivers a stirring rendition. The class thinks she's cra Peggy's decided to have a good time. Announcements begin the PA system. No one pays attention, except Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, students. This is Mr. Mosey. Our girls diving team is competing today in the county finals at Commander Beck High School. We know they'll put forth a splendid effort В— so let's wish them luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Rosalie Testa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably at the diving meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, congratulations go to Richard Norvik for placing first in the Statewide Math Contest. We're proud of you, Richard....That's all, students. Several students boo Richard's name. The BELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maddy, Dolores and Peggy enter the room. Peggy stands at door till most are seated. She sees an empty seat between Maddy and Dolores and, assuming it's hers, sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you study for the test?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Test?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. SNELGROVE, an officious little creep, is standing by desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, class. Time's up. He walks along the aisles collecting the papers. When he to Peggy he picks up her blank sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the meaning of this, Peggy Sue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Snelgrove, I happen to know that in the future, I will never have the slightest use for algebra. And I speak from experience. The class gasps, a few students APPLAUD, and Mr. Snelgrov jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. GILFOND is teaching The Old Man and the Sea. MICHAEL FITZSIMMONS (from reunion crossВ—country photo) is speaki He always wears black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Santiago comes back, with nothing В— there's no meat on the bone. It's Hemingway's ego defending itself again; he's trying to prove he can still perform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What Hemingway's saying, Michael, is that we are alone В— that when we go out too far we're vulnerable. The irony, that Santiago is beaten by the sharks, doesn't make him less of a hero. THE BELL RINGS. The class begins to exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the weekend read the first four chapters of The Great Gatsbv. I hope you enjoy it. Peggy hesitates. She walks up to Gilfond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gilfond, can I talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Peggy Sue. What's on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to tell you how much I enjoy your class. You taught me a lot and... you're a very fine teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Um, I also think you're underpaid.

dialogues.speaker: LUNCH AREA
dialogues.text: Walter, Charlie and Arthur sit at a long table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does your father take inventory on Sunday night? That's poker night. You always got out of it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to string him along for a while. It's for his own good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not going into his business. When're you going to tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon. I can't tall everybody everything all at once. Peggy, Carol and Maddy walk over and sit down with trays. Peggy deliberately avoids the empty sear next to Charlie. They're uneasy with each other. Peggy looks with disgust the slop on the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange rumors are sweeping the school about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prom what I hear, you really gave it to old Smellgrove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was there. She told the creep off right to his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atta girl, Peg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, please don't call me Peg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why I oughta... Charlie, Walter and Arthur crack up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because you' re not a total moron like they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's some stupid old movie thing they just started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough out of you, little lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll throw the book at you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why I oughta... The boys crack up again. The girls think they're hopeless Peggy SEES Michael Fitzsimmons, buried in a book. He look Peggy with a penetrating gaze, then back down. Richard Norvik, also sitting alone, working with a slide ruler on a book of mathematical puzzles, dressed in early Nerd. Peggy gets up from the table. She looks back to Charlie a the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not wasting any time. Peggy Sue and Mr. Square Root?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a nice guy. You know he's writing a book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a book... Excuse me for a second. (fakes gagging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy stands over Richard. He looks up nervously, pushing glasses up the bridge of his nose, a constant habit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations on the math contest, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It really wasn't that difficult. Doug Snell (of MerrillВ—Lynch, at the reunion) walks past

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing, Peggy Sue? Fishing for fourВ—eyed worms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get lost you macho shmuck. Doug and Richard react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to talk to you. It's very important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not doing any tutoring this year. I'm too busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that. Can we meet after school? Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'll be in the physics lab. Make it fourВ—thirty. I have a rocket club meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the walls are several charts: Basic Food Groups, Tips Grooming, and prominently displayed, The Happy Home Corporation, i.e. husband as president, wife, viceВ—presi children, employees, grandparents as board members. MISS stands by her desk. Standing in the front of the room is:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Therefore, the key to a successful children's party can be summed up in one word В— planning.. With proper planning, a successful, inexpensive happy birthday party can be had by all. Including the mother. She walks back to her seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was very comprehensive, Madeline. Thank you.. Now... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue, your topic was 'How To Choose A Nursery School.' Are you  prepared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All.... Okay. Sure. Peggy walks to the front and faces the class, smiling pri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Choosing a good nursery school can be one of the most important decisions you can make. It will often determine your child's attitude towards education and schooling. (proud of herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, the lessons learned are primarily social В—В— sharing, being considerate of others. (remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they're so cute when they're little. They bring you back their Little masterpieces every day and you put 'em on the refrigerator door. They're so proud, and their names are all misspelled. Scott would always print his S backwards, and Beth would make her sweet little flowers... Peggy wipes away a tear. At the stunned reaction of the c and Miss Otto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baseball team practices. Michael Fitzsimmons runs lap with the track team. One lone boy kicks a soccer ball.

dialogues.speaker: A BATON TWIRLING IN THE AIR
dialogues.text: WIDEN to INCLUDE the baton spinning down, falling into th hands of a uniformed majorette who deftly passes it throu her legs and twirls it back into the air. Another baton В rises, spinning awkwardly and falls through Peggy's hands onto the ground. Six MAJORETTES in uniform are practicing Dolores is one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peggy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a girl. What a twirl. You know, PegВ—Leggy, you're gonna get demoted to hall monitor -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Peggy Sue.. Try it again. You haven't been practicing. Peggy gamely tries it again and manages at least to catch baton and continue twirling. She continues, enjoying hers Michael runs by, the lonely long distance runner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group of majorettes heads toward the school. Peggy se Charlie leaning against the car, waving her over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking good out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I noticed you were giving me the silent treatment at lunch. I guess I deserved it. I've been thinking about my three year plan and I think it's unworkable. I must have been delirious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it had a lot of merit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the abstract maybe. Get a grip on yourself! But when I imagine you going out with other guys, I feel... ah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rejected, worthless, miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Peggy turns, and walks away. Charlie looks miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy enters and approaches Richard. He is too engrossed constructing an elaborate kite to notice her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a great kite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm writing a book on kite construction. What did you want to talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to ask you a question. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think...time travel is possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you doing some kind of science project?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... in a Newtonian framework, the possibilities were limited, but with the advent of relativity theory, the idea of absolute time can no longer be reasonably affirmed. Peggy hasn't understood a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, there's Richard's Burrito.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my own theory based on a Mexican food called the burrito. I had it once when my parents took me to Disneyland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I        know what a burrito is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think time is like a burrito. Sometimes it just folds over on itself and one part touches the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can till it with whatever you want. From illusions to memory, from experience to innocence, from happiness to the entire universes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think time travel is possible? For people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. People, dogs, elephants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you've gotta keep this a secret. You can't tell a soul. Promise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is serious. Nobody can know. Ah, I've returned from the future. I traveled back here 25 years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably are crazy. Wait a minute. Is this some kind of joke? I know what you all, think of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Really. You're the smartest person I know. It sounds unbelievable. But I can prove it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a blind grandfather. One day you're going to invent a machine that reads books for blind people. I read about it. You're going to be famous. You're going to invent a lot of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How, did you know about my grandfather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm telling you the truth. I know what's going to happen. There's going to be test tube babies and heart transplants. And an American named Neil Armstrong is going to walk on the moon. On July 20, 1969.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Toledo! That's six years ahead of schedule!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Richard are walking, carrying their books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when did you leave? Are you here until then? Were you there until now? What direction are you going in? Are you a moving point on an infinite line extending into the past? Can anyone do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Oblivious, Peggy and Richard walk by Shower's Cafe. Insid Dolores and Carol see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be very careful if I were you. You don' t want to fall into the clutches of some madman with plans to manipulate your brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I was getting a divorce.. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I really think is that I had a heart attack at the reunion and died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look pretty good for a corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Richard, I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're giving me the creeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I dead or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's one way to find out. Richard stops and throws down his books. He steps in fron Peggy, throwing down her books, dragging her to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confucious says, The way out is through the door. There's a truck. There's your door. A large truck speeds towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step in front of the truck! If you're dead, it won't matter. The truck'll go right through you. Go ahead! You're dead! Peggy takes one step off the curb. The truck is getting closer. The truck BLOWS A LOUD SUSTAINED WAIL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I don't want to die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A completely outfitted laboratory, kites decorate the wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you're not dead, but according to every law of science what you say happened to you is impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if it's beyond science? What it it's God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Einstein said "God doesn't play dice with the universe." I'm a scientist. I believe that there's an order to things. Why would God bring you back as a high school girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a molecule in chaos, a discontinuent aberration. Maybe you've just got powers of precognition. Well, maybe you're just out of whack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, I've already lived my life. I don't know how or why I'm here, but you have to help me get back. I want to get back to my real life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll work on it, I'll, do some research. But in the meantime, don't get crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying. I'll see you tomorrow. (heads out the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if you're not here tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy comes home, enters hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This necklace is sapphire, it was my Grandmother's. Peggy Looks into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mother is sitting on the sofa with a strange MAN in a suit. She's served him tea. There are several, pieces of jewelry spread on a cloth on the coffee table. The man is examining one of the pieces. Mrs. Kelcher seems surprised that Peggy's home from school. Peggy moves on into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy hears her mother let the man out. She enters the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nobody. Ah... he's a poll, taker. I'm thinking of voting Democrat this year. But don't mention it to your father. How was school today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was great to see everybody again. But it's so boring and regimented. Most of what they teach is useless. The worst thing was lunch. The TELEPHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you get that, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Mom. (picking up the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Peggy gasps. Mrs. Kelcher turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy! What's the matter? Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaken)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Grandma. I can't talk to her now. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Grandma. Peggy hands the receiver to her mother and runs out of th room sobbing. Her first confrontation with mortality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy climbs the stairs, in tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue! What is it? Forcing herself to regain her composure, she sits down at top of the landing as Mrs. Kelcher joins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a dream that Grandma died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she is getting on, but she's fine. I told her you weren't feeling well yesterday. She called to find out how you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She did? I love her so much, and I haven't seen her in such a long time. And Grandpa Barney. Is he all, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he's fine, too. You saw them at Easter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mom. I'll call Grandma back and apologize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good girl... I hate to see you so upset. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, sweetheart. Are you having problems with Charlie? You mentioned something this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm confused about a lot of things right now. Charlie's only one of them. Two beats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Charlie pressuring you to do things you don't think you should be doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy, do you know what a penis is? (Peggy's jaw drops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay away from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie pulls up to the curb, opens the glove compartment extracts a can of Old Spice aerosol, sprays the seat; and exits his car, throwing a kiss to it as he walks up to th door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's wearing a hideous orange and turquoise sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kelcher opens the door, Charlie enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, sir. How are things at the hat store?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, thanks. Come on in. I want to talk to you. CAMERA TRACKS Charlie and Mr. Kelcher into the living roo Mr. Kelcher sits on his recliner, Charlie, nervous, on th couch. Nancy is on the rug, studying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may have noticed that Peggy Sue's been acting a little strange lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's distorted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seems confused, irresponsible, overemotional. My wife says that's the way girls act sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's almost a juvenile delinquent. Mr. Kelcher gives Nancy a look and points to the door. Without her father noticing, Nancy creeps up behind him a makes rabbit ears behind his head. Charlie tries hard not laugh. Nancy continues to clown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. But that's what I like about her. She's not like all the other girls at school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, in spite of your adolescent infatuation with music, we've always regarded you a a fine young man. We've trusted you with our daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Trust is a twoВ—way street. In the past two years I've been pleased to note that you and Mrs. Kelcher have, uh, fulfilled your sacred trust of being good parents to the, uh, woman I plan to take off your hands. Mr. Kelcher looks as if he's witnessing the latest attack teenage weirdness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy is changing a record. She sees the dress she was wearing the day before (and at the reunion) slung across chair. As Peggy picks it up, a book of matches falls out. Peggy picks it up, excited. INSERT: MATCHBOOK which reads: FINISH HIGH SCHOOL IN YOUR SPARE TIME. Peggy frantically searches the dress pockets slowly draws out two joints. She stares at them for a bea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worrying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Beth. There's a knock at the door. Peggy quickly hides the join Mrs. Kelcher opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's downstairs. Why aren't you ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maddy's party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel very festive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
