dialogues.text: You accepted an invitation, Maddy's one of your best friends, and I baked the Rice Krispie squares. Peggy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy yourself! This is the best time of your life. And the sooner you learn to handle Charlie the better. Get dressed. Mrs. Kelcher closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think this party might cheer her up. Just make sure you know what's expected of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would that be, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show her a good time, but for God's sake restrain yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: walking downstairs, surprised by Charlie and Dad talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Charlie exit and walk towards his car. Peggy's holding a pan of Rice Krispie squares. Charlie slips Pegg sweater back on her shoulder. He's trying hard to make up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get that sweater?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really Fifties. You sort of clash with the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! What's the fun of being a teenager if you can't dress weird? And we're going to have fun tonight, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. I promised my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this slow enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine Peggy Sue. And how are you? Are we talking on the phone? Are we pen pals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously. What's it like to be eighteen? Charlie looks thoughtful, then guns the engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's great. I cleaned the car, do you like it? Oh, I got tickets for Fabian on your birthday, you like him, right? He's cool. Eighteen is half of thirty six. It's "Gentlemen start your engines", vroom, like I'm gassed up ready for the race. I've got the girl, I've got the car, I've got the talent, but I don't know. Do I date, get married, join the army, cut a record, go to college? I got a million choices, but nobody teaches you how to choose. But it's different for a girl. You're Lucky. You just have to wait for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty kids are dancing, talking, snacking. One couple ma out. Walter, Leon, Terry and Doug Snell are crowded aroun TV, watching an old western with Eugene Pallette or Edgar Buchanan. The boys laugh as Pallette or Buchanan growls a western cliche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gol'darnit, dag nab it, dad burn it, dad blame it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Peggy are poised at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes the life of the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and a few others stand by the bar, where bottles o Coke are lined up. Arthur carefully pours rum from a hip flask directly into the bottles. Peggy and Charlie enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goes down, smooth. Hey, look what the cat dragged in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have no fear. Charlie's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's you is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jumping Jehosophat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a miracle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's a purty little heifer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why Pete's the best darn cook on the Panhandle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why I oughta! The boys all crack up.

dialogues.speaker: THE PARTY
dialogues.text: Walter, Leon, Charlie and Terry crowd around Arthur who h an open, wideВ—mouthed bottle of beer in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready. Set. Go - Arthur rapidly chugВ—aВ—lugs the entire beer and immediat recites from memory as the boys urge him on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going: for speed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HiВ—Yo Silver! A cloud of dust, a galloping horse with the speed of light, a hearty Hi-Yo Silver! The Lone Ranger! With his faithful Indian companion Tonto, the daring and resourceful Masked Rider of the Plains came to Earth with powers- and abilities far beyond those of mortal men. Return with us now to those thrilling days of yesteryear - from out of the... Arthur lets out a huge belch. Everybody cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You doorknob! You threw in Superman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad. Close to a record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (foaming at the nose)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate it when the beer comes out my nose.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER AREA
dialogues.text: Peggy, Carol and Maddy bemusedly watching the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe I want to marry that dork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do guys do such stupid things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I never could figure that one out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maddy, Arthur, Walter, Carol, Charlie and Peggy sit on a couch. Maddy and Carol sit in their boyfriends' laps. Peg sits distractedly on the couch arm. They cross talk В— bo boys В— girls to girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking of four ushers and four bridesmaids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Yanks got the hitting but the Sox got the defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are your colors, going to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'l1 take Kubek and Richardson over Fox and Aparicio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of pink and green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores and Terry standing in a corner kissing passionate

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at Dolores. What a tramp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pitching wins pennants. The Tigers got four potential twenty game winners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised at how many girls in school aren't virgins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Carol)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don Mossi, Frank Lary, Jim Sunning and Paul Foytack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, direct from three weeks of rehearsal in Walter's garage, four guys who have dedicated their lives to becoming the greatest singing group in the world... (beat) Charlie, Walter, Leon and Terry. The Definitions. Applause as the group enters from the furnace room. They wear black pants and iridescent sharkskin jackets. Charli in the center of the group as they position themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, two, three-... The group begins to SING an A CAPELLA version of RAMA LAM DING DONG (or I WONDER WHY). Charlie sings lead, backed u the other three. Walter dances insane, TemptationВ—like s The crowd huddles around them, clapping and grooving. Peg is on the planet of lost innocence, removed and melanchol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie really has a great voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they'll be the next Dion and the Belmonts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get your hopes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, where's your enthusiasm? Charlie SINGS directly to Peggy, grinning at her. In spit herself, she smiles back at him. She's starting to realiz why she fell in love with him. He's irresistible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is kind of cute, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You're so lucky. He really loves you, too. He's always telling Walter how wonderful you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does? The group finishes the song. Charlie blows Peggy a kiss. crowd APPLAUDS, including Peggy. Dolores joins Peggy, Car and Maddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and I saw you with that creep, Richard, today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, Richard is not a creep. He happens to be an exceptional person. If any of you gave him half a chance, you'd find that out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, Peggy, you're so unformed you're practically fetal. You're just taking pity on him 'cause he has no friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores, can't you be a little kinder to people? You don't even know the boy. If you weren't so neurotic and insecure, maybe you'd shut up for a while and show some compassion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you for real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touchy, touchy! Dolores storms away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Peggy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you said to her, but I wish I'd said it. Charlie and Walter walk over and accept "BRAVOS" from the girls. Walter does his James Dean imitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, what do you think of Richard Norvik?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he gonna help you with that physics stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Who needs physics when we've got chemistry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (charmed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put on some makeВ—out music, and kill the lights. We HEAR a RECORD SCRATCH. A slow song begins. The lights dimmed. Coupler begin to slow dance. Charlie holds Peggy close, barely moving. Peggy is mistyВ—eyed, moved by bein Charlie's arms again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't a girl in school that can hold a candle to you..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pretty charming when you want to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah I know.  But I don't have to flatter you.  It just feels right.  You're the perfect girl for me.  As in is, was and always will be.  I'm glad dancing was invented.  You know the first dances were rituals.  Like fertility rites. As they dance Charlie gets embarrassed by an erection, an moves his hips away from Peggy.  She surprises him by grabbing his tush and pulling him into her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC FADES INTO the song "PARTY DOLL" by Buddy Knox. Peggy is doing the Twist, showing Charlie and several oth Walter gets the hang of it, twisting on one leg.  Carol t to keep up.  Maddy and Arthur are always a beat behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Terry, what is that?  Did Peggy make it up?  I've never seen that on Bandstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we're witnessing the end of touch dancing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windows are fogged.  Peggy and Charlie kiss tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. This is nice.  I always loved the way you kiss.  I missed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your eyes look like silver pools of moonlight.  And the tide rushes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really love me, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I do.  I even wrote you into my will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tentatively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, let's make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! You mean sex?! Intercourse? (nonВ—believing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to have intercourse! Last weekend you said... What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot's happened since last weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're the one who wanted to wait till we got married. And you were right. We should wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (f1ustered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I probably meant it when I said it. (beat; coyly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't Lucky Chuckie want to come out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Peggy starts to GIGGLE, realizing the absurdity of the situation. The more she GIGGLES, the more agitated Charli gets. Peggy starts to unbutton Charlie's shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know. Your love machine... the throbbing thrill hammer... your thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean my wang? Listen, it's running real late. Charlie pushes her away, angry..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? What the hell is going on? One week you say, "If you love me you won't", now you say "If you love me you will". (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. That's a guy's line! Peggy realizes she's blown it. Charlie isn't ready for th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a mistake. We better forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're damn right! Jesus! Peggy! You sure know how to spoil a mood. Charlie straightens himself up, starts the car and burns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie drops her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save it. Peggy watches him go. Looking at her darkened house, she turns and walks down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy peeks in the window. The kids from the party are ea and laughing. Rosalie Testa is dancing. Shaken by Rosalie she turns away. In the distance she SEES the lights of: ART'S DONUT HOLE. OPEN 24 HOURS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few people linger over coffee. The waitress serving the Monica (the same but younger woman from LOVIN' OVEN). In a corner, Michael Fitzsimmons, in a red leather jacket sits alone, reading. He looks up to check on his motorcyc parked outside. He's splendid in his isolation. Peggy enters, taking a seat at the counter, startled to s Monica, who doesn't know her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monica? Aren't you Monica Hines?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah... never mind. Can I have a coffee, please? And a cinnamon cruller. (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Bobo? Peggy notices Michael staring at her. Peggy smiles, Micha doesn't. Monica brings Peggy her coffee and donut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty cents, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding? Picking up her donut and coffee, she walks over to Michae table and sits opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was impressed with what you said in English class today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilfond's okay, except he thinks Hemingway's great Literature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a fisherman! The most overrated writer of the century. I mean, he's the perfect American author В— fat, violent, drunk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're confusing his life with his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A writer's life is his work. Jack Kerouac doesn't have to kill a bull to have something to write about. He's out there feeling, burning... grooving on life! Michael leans back in his chair. He's said his piece. Peg studies him for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young man leaned back in his chair. No bulls would die today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing here anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee and a donut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought chicks like you traveled in packs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, I'm a hip chick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long shot of the brightly lit donut shop. Michael and Peg are clearly visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores and Terry are driving by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry, slow down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry! Slow down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Michael leave the donut shop, get on Michael's motorcycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's Peggy with Michael Fitzsimmons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That commie beatnik? What's she doing with him? Wait'll I tell Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First a nerd and then a weirdo. What a bunch of nose pickers. I'll tell Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy on Michael's bike, clasped around him. Her eyes clo enjoying the wind blowing in her hair. They head out of t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael pumps gas. Peggy walks to the washrooms. Looking around she waits a beat, then enters the men's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all the aplomb of a divorcee, Peggy takes a quarter deposits it in a condom machine. She puts the packet in h skirt pocket, pulls out the joints and stares at them for beat. She checks her hair in the mirror and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael pumps air into the tires, bunched against a build Peggy approaches him, holding up a joint, smiling conspiratorially. She lights it, inhales deeply, then pas it to him. He smiles back at her, a bit surprised, but st takes the joint and inhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive up to a mountain top, Peggy wearing the leathe jacket. She directs Michael with one arm. The motorcycle is parked. Peggy and Michael lie on the gr staring down at the town lights below. Michael inhales th joint, then passes it to Peggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is great reefer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm surprised. It's really old... (inhales) Travels well though. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, the world looks a lot better from up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world is fantastic. It's the ultimate absurd circus. I am shot from a cannon into the energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you shooting for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maximum intensity. Yeah. I can't wait to get out of here. I'm gonna write. I'm gonna check out of this bourgeois motel. Push myself away from the dinner table and say 'No more JellВ—O for me, Mom.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you get along with your parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing my father digs is cold, green money. All my mother cares about is her standing at the country club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They care about you. They're just a different generation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey what's with you? I thought you were cool. You rode my bike. You  blew some pot. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your scene Miss Majorette? You gonna marry Mr. Blue Impala and graze around with all the other sheep for the rest of your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already did that. I want to be a dancer, I want to dance. Peggy takes off her sweater, kicks off her shoes and begi to dance. Her eyes are closed, her body silhouetted by th moon. Michael is transfixed. After a few beats, he walks to her. He stretches out his arms and places them around neck. They sway together for several beats, their bodies touching. Peggy opens her eyes and sees Michael gazing at tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I had you pegged all wrong. Michael kisses Peggy. She responds passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ray of oneness piercing the solitude. Falling bodies in the ecstasy of flesh. You'll be a chapter in my memoirs of desire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that one of your poems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just made that up. Do you want to hear one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes ablaze)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Here's a new one. It's called Tenderness. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't sleep so I thought I'd scream Betrayed by a kiss, sucking pods of bitterness. In the madhouse of Dr. Dread Razor shreds of rat puke fall On my bare arms (sees Peggy grimace; he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: calms down) I'm sorry. I guess I was trying to impress you. (kisses her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy is falling for it. He fumbles with her bra straps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael... you're as good as you looked. His other hand reaches to undo her skirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll respect you for eternity. (reciting tenderly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'When you are old and gray, and full of sleep, And nodding by the fire, Take down this book, and slowly read, And dream of the soft look your eyes had once." (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't write that. That's Yeats. Peggy is moved by the beauty of the poem. She sits up, le over Michael, runs her hand through his hair, almost motherly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I envy you. You have your whole life ahead of you and you know exactly what you want to do. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But forget the rat puke; write something beautiful. Peggy lies back down on the ground. Michael takes her han and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, this isn't really happening. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include the entire, perfect tableau: starry night, the motorcycle, the clouds racing across th moon and the two lovers on the mountaintop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael stops at the corner of Peggy's street. She gets o the bike and kisses Michael goodbye. He takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy walks up the path as the MILKMAN approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your parents are waiting up. You know, I see a lot of this in the spring. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Ralph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy enters, trying to be quiet. Mr. Kelcher stands in kitchen doorway in his bathrobe waiting for her, steaming CAMERA TRACKS Peggy into kitchen. She grabs a cup of before sitting down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went for a drive. Up in the hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn that Charlie I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Charlie. It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy, let me ask you something. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not... expecting are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At my age? Don't be silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad.. it's not a big deal. Didn't you ever stay out all night when you were young?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but I was a boy. And I still had hell to pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down. Just listen for a minute.. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. But this better be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to help with the family finances. I want you to buy some stocks. And gold. By 1980 gold is going to be worth eight hundred dollars an ounce. Then you sell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how ridiculous you sound? First of all, it's illegal for U.S. citizens to buy gold. And in the second place, the price of gold is regulated by the government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're going to deregulate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your problems The more women think, the more trouble they get into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh boy, that's another thing that's going to change. Who's going to think for us? Our husbands? You know, you treat Mom like a maid. It's not entirely your fault. Those were the attitudes in the fifties, and that's the way you raised me. But give Nancy a break, encourage her to go to art school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard just about enough of this lunacy! Go to your room!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen Dad, please. Buy IBM, buy Polaroid, buy Apple Computer. No, no. Not yet. Buy Xerox!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn, take her to her room! Peggy stalks out of the kitchen to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not the maid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way to go, Mom! The Kelchers glare at each other~. We HEAR the DOOR SLAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Richard sit in a booth. Richard's kite is hung coat rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way I see it, you have an unparalleled opportunity to become the richest woman in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just not the type. Besides, I want to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have a vision. Don't you want to help your parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to tell them, but they wouldn't listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about invention, no investment. I know what people think of me. Mr. Spasmatician. Dick the Square Root. I'll show them. You said I was going to be a millionaire. And you're gonna help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No offense, but for a person who says she's lived an extra lifetime, you certainly are thick. Money is power.. Money makes people respect you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you never ask me any important questions? Don't you wonder if there's going to be a nuclear war? Or a cure for cancer? What about your family? What about people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm curious, but I don't want to know. Jeez, I hope you haven't been telling people what's going to happen to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me some credit, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. You're discreet. I like that in a partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wbat're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look it's very simple. You tell me everything that hasn't been invented yet, and I'll invent it. We'll be partners. FiftyВ—fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SixtyВ—forty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, find yourself another vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're taking advantage of a minor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do we start? A WAITRESS approaches their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Ton on a Bun, with fries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiche Lorraine, spinach salad and a Perrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street is filled with Saturday shoppers. Peggy holds kite, Richard takes notes as they windowshop. They stop i front of a dry cleaners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dry cleaners. No real change. Just higher prices. They move next door to a shoe store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. This is a biggie. Forget sneakers. Running shoes, jogging shoes, tennis shoes. Fifty to two hundred dollars a pair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. You can't be serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are major fortunes to be made here. Leisure time and lifeВ—styles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you talking ~about exercise? Like gym?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for you. Okay, there's lots more. They move along to the next window, an appliance store. T window is filled with old televisions, record players, la rotisserieВ—broilers, etc. The store sign reads: BODELL'S AND APPLIANCES. Another sign reads: COME IN AND LISTEN TO STEREOPHONIC SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that stuff. It's like the dark ages. This is more your speed. And boy, do I know this business. Peggy peers into the store again and catches a g1impse of Charlie serving a customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Richard sit on the bench next to TWO OLD. LADIE Richard reads from his list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see... (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: icrowavemays, ocketpay alculatorcays... The two ladies react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to use pig Latin! Nobody could possibly know what we're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. These are the choices: microwave ovens, pocket calculators, Walkmans, digital watches and miniature TV's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.        And huge portable radios. Everything else gets small, but for some reason, portable radios get enormous. Peggy looks up and sees a lingerie store across the stree She heads towards it, calling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back. Peggy enters the Lingerie store. After a beat, Peggy emer from the store, excited and empty handed. Dodging traffic she hurries back to Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard! They don't have any! They never heard of them! Isn't that wonderful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wave of the future! I've decided on our first fortune! I'll  see you later. You just think high tech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High tech. I like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the back is a small record department, complete with a listening booth. Charlie is waiting on a customer. Peggy enters. CHARLIE'S FATHER is waiting on a buxom YOUNG WOMA his arm around her shoulder. He turns around as she enter She has a shock of recognition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to young woman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that freezer chest. What capacity. (to Peggy, embarrassed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Peggy Sue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody! How ya doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, just fine. Peggy gives him a big hug and a kiss on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's in the back. Peggy walks towards the back as Mr. Bodell explains:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My future daughterВ—inВ—law. Very affectionate girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie talks to on ELDERLY GENTLEMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just take the Ravel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the Shostakovich home and listen to it. Let it grow on you. Everyone that's bought it has come back and said, "This is definitive Shostakovich. Thank you for encouraging me to investigate it."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I did enjoy the Dvorak you suggested. Young man, you talked me into it. Charlie points Peggy to the listening booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll like it. I kid you not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy sits on the chair. A turntable sits on a small desk Record covers decorate the walls. Charlie enters and sits the desk, his feet resting on Peggy's chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about classical music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.. Selling is selling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie. About last nights..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. I've been thinking. Girls must go through that stuff too. Sometimes when I look at you I feel like an animal. Maybe my dad's right. Teenagers are nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not. I'm a grown woman with a lifetime of emotional experiences you couldn't possibly understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. Girls mature faster than guys. But last night, I was the one who put on the brakes. And you know why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Charlie cups her face in his hands, pouring out his heart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because nothing else matters. That's the great thing about love. Every time we argue, every time something goes wrong, and I know that I'm not perfect either, things just work out better in the end. Cause you're my baby and I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going to do with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be cruel to a heart that's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone in the store, Mr. Kelcher is going through some receipts. Peggy enters carrying a shopping bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing some shopping? Peggy reaches into the shopping bag and pulls out a small wrapped box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open it. He opens the present.  Inside are a pair of miniature gol ball cufflinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, they're beautiful. But they must've been expensive. Across the street an ice cream truck pulls up. Mothers, fathers and children crowd around the back as the driver the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I closed my Christmas club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, you got your money out of that greedy bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to apologize for this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to believe you're going to be eighteen. (looks out the window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want an eskimo pie? Or a creamsicle? I'd come home from the store and there's little you running up to me. I'd give you a dime and you'd promise never to grow up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This morning was good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hat business is in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, that what all that nonsense was about this morning? You're worried about my business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very thoughtful, honey. It's just a slump. Things will pick up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when John F. Kennedy's elected President, men'1l stop wearing hats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kennedy's a Catholic. He'll never win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely; closing her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eyes) He'll win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard Nixon's going to be President. Nixon wears hats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy is helping her sister Nancy with an art project.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think this'll cheer Dad up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, he'll love it. You're a terrific artist. We HEAR Mr. Kelcher arguing loudly from downstairs. The t girls freeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need your charity. I don't need your grandmother's jewelry or your parents money -В—how could you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't shout. Peggy opens the door, Nancy cautiously behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not shouting. Have we ever starved? Have we ever missed a mea1?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kelcher moves around the room, closing the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does everybody have to hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want everybody to hear because I don't have anything to be ashamed of. Mr. Kelcher collapses into his barcalounger, red as a bee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, I was just trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll make it, we'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy is frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this mean we're going to be poor? Peggy leads her back into her room without letting her parents know they were there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR the song "Stranger in Paradise" from Kismet on th old black and white record player from opening scene. Peg sits on the floor, surrounded by stockings, leotards and sewing basket. She cuts the legs oft a pair of leotards. one hand she holds up the top half of the leotards, in th other hand, a pair of nylon stockings. We HEAR a KNOCK on the bedroom door. Peggy pushes everyth under the bed as Maddy and Carol enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. What's the scoop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come we're your best friends and we had to find out about you and Michael Fitzsimmons from Dolores?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's unbelievable. Who needs satellites when we've got Dolores's mouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear she does more than talk with her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's disgusting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brushing her hair) )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Maddy, grow up. It says in LOVE WITHOUT FEAR that "the tongue kiss as a means of genital stimulation is widely practiced and has much to commend it". Page eightyВ—six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you memorize the whole book or only the good parts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what you underlined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding...? Carol, you have beautiful hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. What's with you and Michael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's so cool and mysterious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's very interesting. For all his pretending to be a tough guy, he's really got the soul of a poet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet Dolores told Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That loudВ—mouthed little bitch~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better watch out for her. She's after Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool it kids. He's free to see other girls, if he wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I always thought that you would marry Charlie, Carol would marry Walter, and I would marry Arthur. We'd all live on the same street and take our kids to the park together and have barbecues every Sunday. It'll spoil everything if you and Charlie break up. That Michael doesn't look like the barbecue type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to marry him. I just went out with him once. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! Why don't we go to the movies tonight. Just us girls. It'll be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly. It's Saturday. Date night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I've gotta go. Arthur's picking me up soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. But let's have a girls night soon. Maybe a pajama party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we a little old for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes you're so immature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy turns to face her parents, holding up her homeВ—mad pantyhose with a flourish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ta da! Pantyhose! The death of the garter belt! Of course, once they're manufactured they'll look better than this. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your great invention? (to Mrs. Kelcher)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you wear those things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would they go over my girdle or under?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead of a girdle. And light as a feather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, I think she's got something there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we won't just sell them in department stores. We'll market them in drug stores and  supermarkets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all well and good, but we don't have the money to manufacture them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a partner. There's a friend of mine at school whose father makes seat covers for cars, Mr. Fitzsimmons. I've invited him and his family over for dinner tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that awfully forward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to move fast. This is an idea whose time has come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to tell me that you invited this Mr. Fitzsimmons over to talk about investing his money in your cockamamie idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong, Dad. Your idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A breeze blows through the open window Peggy sleeps fitfu tossing off the covers. We HEAR NOISES from outside her window. A figure appears outside and silently climbs into bedroom. Peggy mumbles Charlie's name. The man walks over her bed as Peggy reaches out for him, tenderly, as if the were still married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie. I just had the strangest dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to talk to you.. Through her sleepВ—clouded eyes, Peggy begins to focus on face of the younger Charlie. Suddenly, she remembers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go down to the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy enters, flicks on the light and leads Charlie in. P senses Charlie's anger, and steels herself for the inevit confrontation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know what's going on. Dolores told me that you and that scuzzball Michael Fitzsimmons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bumped into him after you dropped me off Last night. I didn't feel like going home, so we went for a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's true, dammit! I had a miserable time tonight 'cause of you. When the Monotones did "Book of Love В—В— Chapter Four you break up, won't you give it just one more chance..." I'm thinking Did we break up? 'Cause if we did, I don't even know about it!. I thought we cleared all that up yesterday. Did that Maynard G. Beatnik give you what you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I never could stand your sarcasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to blow it, Peggy Sue. Nobody treats Charlie Bodell like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why do you always refer to yourself in the third person, like Napoleon? How come it always turns into an argument with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I've got the hair, got the eyes, got the teeth, I got the car. I'm the lead singer, I'm the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie,. I've been trying to postpone this. But what's the point? It's over. (crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to hurt you. This is very hard for me. I'm doing this for both of us. I really want you to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be happy if I have you. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't make any difference. We just can't live together. And you had the nerve to drive up with that bimbo Janet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? Who's Janet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can't trust you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about everything I said to you this afternoon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just it. You can always get to me. There's this window in my heart and every time I leave it open, you climb in. Unless I close it now, nothing's ever going to be different!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what has to be different?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything. I have a good head for business, I should be franchising the bakery. And I want you to give me your word that whatever happens, you'll go to college. And finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What! What about the group and my singing career? What about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to save you years of frustration... waiting for a big break... no. Waiting for that big disappointment so you could blame it all on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know zip! You think I'm going to end up selling appliances like my father? Chasing women around the store. I've got to give it a shot. Why are you trying to kill the two things that mean the most to me? Until yesterday you loved me and you loved us. (opening the door) )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell has changed? For two years I've done nothing but love you. I'll show you, I'm going to be just like Fabian! Charlie exits. Peggy slumps back, drained. Getting up, sh crosses to the mounted swordfish. Standing on a chair she reaches into the mouth of the fish and pulls out a packag Pall Malls. She puts a cigarette in her mouth and picks u table lighter and flicks it. As it lights, the tiny music inside PLAYS SMOKE GETS IN YOUR EYES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR distant CHURCH BELLS. Peggy sits down to scan the large Sunday newspaper. Seeing her mother's phone book, s finds the number she needs and picks up the phone. She di slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very nervous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Grandma. It's Peggy Sue. Much better. How are you? I'm very sorry about the other day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy jogs towards Richard. He is watering the front lawn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jogging. I was running, now I'm jogging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you were talking about yesterday? Everybody does that in the future?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. It's going to be a law. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I broke up with Charlie last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's terrific. You did it. You really changed the course of your destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an unfair fight. He didn't have a chance. I'm taking a real gamble. I loved him for a long, long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheer up. Now you can give some other guy a shot. Make it up to him later and buy him a yacht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, forget the money! I'm going crazy! I'm a walking anachronism. I'm a puddle of deja I'm worried about my kids, Scott must be scared to death, I think my daughter's doing drugs again. I can't have any fun here, I don't have that innocence any more. I can't keep all this in anymore. I feel Like I'm going to explode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, the best scientific mind in this country is working on your case. May I make a suggestion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suggestion! Hypnotic suggestion! Why didn't I think o~ that before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about hypnosis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything. This is perfect. The subconscious mind remembers all. You can give me more information on microchips and then pinpoint what happened at the reunion. Maybe that'll give us a clue on how to get you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm desperate. I'll try anything. But what if you can't snap me out of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No offense, but you're pretty out of it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy sits in an old recliner. Richard holds a small, batteryВ—operated revolving disc up in front of Peggy's c eyes, then puts it down and picks up a notepad and pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are completely relaxed. When I count to three, you will open your eyes. One... two... three. (Peggy's eyes flutter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: open) We'll start with something easy. What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tranceВ—like)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue Kelcher. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or, Peggy Bodell. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh boy. Peggy, what are microchips?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah..... they're very tiny... they look like a fingernail made out of an erector set...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will they be made of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's called silicon. Charlie told me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silicon is from sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were lying in the sand. It was my eighteenth birthday... We were so awkward... I would have married him anyway... Peggy starts to shift in the chair. Her shorts hike up, h legs spread slightly. This is not lost on Richard. Weird, guttural sounds begin to emanate from his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the future, will you have to marry a girl before you have sex with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The Pill will change all that. Then he wouldn't have blamed me. We were just too young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you'll give a girl a pill and she'll want to have sex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The Pill will be for birth control. But girls do like sex. Maybe not the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you take of f your blouse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, every day. (taking her blouse off В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: getting spaced)  Maybe I shouldn't have worn that dress? I told Beth it was a bad idea. That's why they made me Queen. Peggy's meandering makes Richard nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard, are you in there? Richard frantically tries to put Peggy's blouse back on. She's limp and unresponsive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Yes! I'll be right out, Dad. (urgent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit! Peggy, I'm going to snap you out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't help it В—В— I loved him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One... two... three. (claps twice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are now awake. Richard kneels on top of Peggy as she wakes up, fumbling buttons at her breasts. Peggy comes to, as Richard jumps She buttons her blouse, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard! You should be ashamed of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? You went crazy! You started taking your clothes off. I was putting them back on for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just perfect isn't it? Did it work? Did you find out why I came back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it has something to do with your birthday. You were rambling. I didn't understand the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God dammit! How'm I gonna got out of here? Peggy grabs a glass beaker and hurls it against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Do you have any idea how much those beakers cost? I usually charge for hypnosis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, go feel up your hamsters! I hear rodents put out. Peggy storms out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kelcher stands at the counter preparing a pot roast. Peggy's making a chocolate mousse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, dear, I think the pantyhose is a wonderful idea, but the next time you come up with something, please don't stay out all night. Just tell us. We'll believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, how about a machine that's like your blender, only it slices vegetables, kneads dough, chops meat and even make fresh pasta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's pasta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Mrs. Kelcher are setting the table, taking the china out of the cabinet. A dozen red roses grace the tab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These roses are beautiful. And so romantic'. Who is this Michael? Is he a friend of Charlie's? She moves the Jell-O mold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, just a friend of mine. I don't think he Likes JellВ—O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does Charlie think about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Mom, it's okay to have male friends. Besides, it's over with me and Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? When did it happen? Your dad and I always expected you two to get married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know Peggy Sue gets married. Case closed. Period. Mom, if you could live your life over again, would you do the same thing? Get married and settle down after high school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I loved your Lather. I remember once being offered a scholarship to art school. But I turned it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the college girls I knew were so well, dressed. I was worried that I wouldn't fit in. I didn't have the right clothes. I was so silly. But, I don't have many regrets, and besides, r don't have time to worry about the past. But Charlie. I hope you know what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, DORIS and ED FITZSIMMONS sit at the table with t Kelchers. They have just finished dessert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moose?  I never thought I'd have moose for desert. The adults laugh. Michael looks bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue cooked the whole dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mom helped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you should open a restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's incredibly difficult to make money in the restaurant business. You have to get up at five in the morning to go to the market, you have problems with spoilage, employee pilferage, and just try and collect from the credit card companies. They take months to pay. The whole table is astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does a young gal like you know so much about business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I just picked it up from my dad. He's a wonderful businessman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Peggy gives her father a go get him look. Michael's writi in a pocket notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Ed, why don't you and I adjourn to the den for a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy~ and Michael stand by Michael's motorcycle, passing cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was quite an evening. Bourgeois, phony, decadent, stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have put you through that. It must have been agony. Let's do something. Michael makes a move towards Peggy, with lust in his eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Something else. I'm too full. Besides, it's a school night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Peggy pull up on the motorcycle in front of Lena's Lounge, a seedy bar in the town's black ghetto. Ha dozen blacks are banging around outside. They eye Peggy a Michael suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has a bar at one side, booths and tables in the of the room. A stage is at the far end. On stage, an all black group, The FourВ—Mations, is performing the song GO TIMIN' The people in the club are dancing the Twist. Peggy and Michael sit in the last booth. Several people w hello to Michael.. Although Peggy and Michael can see the stage, their booth is not visible from the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five more weeks of school. And ten minutes past graduation I'm gone. (he raises his glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around at the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: crowd В— clinking glasses) For everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen, this is the plan. As soon as school is finished we go to Utah and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Utah? I thought you'd be going to New York or Paris. What's in Utah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita. I met her last summer. She's cool. You'll really dig her. She's got this great little cabin in the hills, just outside of Provo where she raises chickens. I'll write and the two of you can take care of the chickens to support us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astounded)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Polygamy's legal in Utah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate chickens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On stage, the FourВ—Nations have concluded their song. We HEAR APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Now we're happy to introduce, a friend of ours. He's one damn fine singer, Mr. Charlie Dell! We HEAR the GROVE BEGIN the SONG SEA OF LOVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about the other night? We were like two stars in the same constellation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, you and I are light years apart. You should go, but not with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we had heat baby. Passion! Fire! We owe it to ourselves to fuse together. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least one more time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a terrific line. You're going to be a wonderful writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We had a glorious night together. One day you'll remember and write about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can dig that. Bittersweet perfection. Dogs of lust on leashes of memory... yeah. Suddenly distracted by the familiar voice, Peggy looks up the stage and sees that the lead singer, Charlie Bell, is fact, Charlie Bodell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a treat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE SINGING
dialogues.text: MICHAEL. Michael observes Peggy's intimate reaction to Charlie's singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssh. He's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue's still stuck on treble without a cause. Charlie finishes the song as the audience goes wild. He beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I knew everything about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we split now? Peggy and Michael unobtrusively slip out of the club. Cha leaves the stage. He's met by a greasy looking MAN. They down at a booth to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael and Peggy pull up. Peggy gets off the bike and gi Michael a goodВ—night kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can dig you being uptight about Rita and Utah. That's cool. But I've got to warn you about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father. He's not just the ultimate square. He's a total crook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kelcher finishes the dishes, with rubber gloves on. Kelcher sits, cleaning his pipe. Peggy enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it go with the pantyhose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the darndest thing. Ed knew what they were immediately. As a matter of fact, he said he's got a product like that in development right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't call, them pantyhose, though. What was it, Evelyn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheerotards. Catchy name, isn't it?  Like leotards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a liar! He has no such thing! It's my own fault. I should have had it patented first. He's a crook, damnit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue, watch your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Fitzsimmons is a very prominent man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're both so naive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look young lady, I grew up through the depression. I fought in the second World War. Six days a week I get up and deal with the public, the bank and the bill collectors. And on the seventh day, when God rests, I don't have to listen to my daughter calling me a fool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a point, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (POSS. OMIT THIS SCENE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy lies in bed in the darkness, her eyes wide open. Th bedside clock reads: 2:47. Peggy gets out of bed. CAMERA TRACKS Peggy into Nancy's room. Peggy looks down a Nancy sleeping. Gently pulling back the blankets, Peggy g into bed with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy walks down a residential street, much like her parents'. She stops when she sees Charlie's car parked in driveway, and leans against a tree next to his car. Momen later, Charlie exits his house, a dog trailing behind him The dog runs up to Peggy. Charlie is wary and distant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to talk to you, and I have one last thing to take care of at school. Then I'm going to... (pats dog)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good dog, Rusty. Good dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rusty's dead. That's Ajax Charlie throws a stick. Ajax chases it, never comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I guess I always liked Rusty better. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you give me a ride to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, the Blue Thunder's out of commission for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how about a walk, Charlie Bell..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at Lena's last night. You were terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not terrific enough. What were you doing in that part of town? Who were you with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were You doing there? You never told me you were singing with an R and B group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. I guess there's a lot of things we don't know about each other. Charlie and Peggy walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd forgotten how much music meant to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's real big of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop being defensive. I want to help you. I wrote a song for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding. You wrote a song? Is it about a guilty girl and a trusting guy... she wants to hurt him, and he wonders why? Peggy takes a piece of paper from her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly, but with your great voice, it'll be a huge hit. Honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fat chance. You know, Lee Wilkins came to hear me last night. He told me to forget it. You told me to forget it. My parents tell me to forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just take a look at it. (hands him the lyric)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you took the trouble to write it, then sure, I'll take a look at it. But I'm beginning to think that maybe there's more to life than music. I wonder if people would still like me if I stopped being Mr. Excitement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Charlie stand by their open locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this mean you like me again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means I care about you and what happens to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I wanted to hear. 'Cause I'm never going to give up on us. It's easy to fall apart in a crisis. It's easy to be selfish and say goodbye and good luck. But this is more than love. This is a mental decision. Just wait till tomorrow, when you see your birthday present. Then you'll understand. Charlie walks away as Peggy reaches into the locker for h books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy, I have to talk to you. Peggy turns to Carol. They walk down the hallway together

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that jerk Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After Charlie told Walter that he broke up with you because he wanted to play the field, Walter decided he should do the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the singles' scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a I going to do for the rest of my life? I don't have a boyfriend anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Carol, maybe Walter's done you a big favor. You always said you wanted to get out of town. Go for it. And be happy, goddamnit, I'm rooting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter walks up to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Charlie, what do you think of this? Walter does a totally demented dance step, finishing by strumming his leg like a guitar. He stands there grinning

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, maybe you should be a dentist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy sits at her desk, organizing her books. We hear the of the ANNOUNCEMENTS over the P.A. SYSTEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And finally, our heartiest congratulations to our girls diving team for placing second in the county finals last Friday. And a special accolade to Rosalie Testa who placed first in every one of her events. We're proud of you, Rosalie. Everybody turns toward Rosalie and applauds. Peggy turns Rosalie, trembling. The BELL RINGS as the class starts to leave, still crowded around Rosalie. Peggy stares after h frozen in her seat Dolores approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, princess? Lost your prince? Peggy looks up at Dolores and starts to seethe. She stand slowly and faces Dolores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Dolores, there's a lot of things I could say to you, but you're not worth the effort. Peggy reaches down to        up her books. On the top of an open fountain pen, which she picks up, pul1ing the rel lever, squirting ink all over Dolores's dress. Dolores dr her books, looks down at her dress, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. These fountain pens are so tricky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! You did that on purpose! I hate you. Go gargle with razor blades!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a long walk on a short pier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy sits disconsolate on a bench, watching the other gi changing into their swim suits. Rosalie is in the shower room, wetting down her suit. She accepts congratulations a number of the girls. The BELL RINGS as the girls begin exit to the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosalie! Wait! Rosalie turns at the door, smiling. They are alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should give up diving. It's dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly, I'm the best in the county.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you are, but you have to stop. I couldn't tell you before, I didn't know if I should. But you have to stop before you hurt yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spend three hours a day practicing. I have trainers, I know what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But accidents can happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to me they don't. I'm going to win the State, then the. Nationals, and then I'm going to the Olympics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rosalie, please, listen to me! You have to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sick. You should go to the nurse. I'm going to tell Miss Dennis. Rosalie exits into the pool area. Peggy feels helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy walks down the hall, a set of double doors, leading the pool, just ahead of her through them she sees Rosalie diving through the air with the careless innocence of you Burdened with the inevitability of it all, she rushes thr the hall, and is stopped by Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all, gone wrong, nothing's working out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not true.  I think I'm making real progress on the microchip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were meant to. You're one of those fortunate people that good things happen to. I have to get out of here. She starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy, I believe you. I believe everything you told me. It's wonderful. You're the exception that proves the rule. She kisses him on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too, Richard. Thanks for trying. She continues down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy heads out the door, sees Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Peggy. Wait a minute. Peggy stops on the landing. Charlie joins her, so eager. doesn't notice how distraught she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cut shop and did some work on your song. You know, it's not half bad for your first try. Of course, I changed all the "yeahs" to "oohs". Listen to this. Charlie begins to sing an R&B version of SHE LOVES YO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, it'll never work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Listen, I cancelled the tickets for Fabian. I thought it would be better for your birthday to eat at a nice restaurant, Chez Tres. Walter, Arthur, Maddy and Carol watch as Peggy runs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT the bus, Peggy looking out the window, the rural scenery: pastures, barns, etc., the other passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy's grandparents, ELIZABETH and BARNEY ALVORG , wait the front of the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy sees her grandparents waiting for her.  She grips t window rail tightly, trying to hold herself together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody gettin' off at Dumont. Here we are. Peggy stands and reaches above to take down her suitcase. Nervous, she drops it. A MAN, getting off the bus, helps picking it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble at all.  The man gets off the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy stands at the door of the bus, hesitant. Elizabeth Barney approach the bus, waving and smiling up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Lilla!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Sue! Peggy slowly walks down the steps, moved to tears. She approaches her grandparents and drops her suitcases. She them tightly. The bus door closes and the bus pulls away behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney is behind the wheel of a 1951 Plymouth. Elizabeth in front, Peggy curled up in the back, regressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a bit more rain than usual this year. I hope it doesn't spoil the rhubarb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already got some in. I was thinking of making a pie for dinner tonight. (turning around to Peggy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a little girl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  (beat) )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandma, would you teach me how to make strudel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a day's work. But if that's what you want, maybe we can do it tomorrow for your birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Elizabeth finish up the dishes, chatting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire blazes in the fireplace. A grandfather clock stand prominently in the room. The clock from Peggy's house. Peggy sits with Elizabeth, learning how to knit. Barney laughs at "The Burns and Allen Show" on TV. Suddenly, Peggy places her hand over her heart and shiver with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Lilla? Somebody jump on your grave? Peggy shivers again and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney reading. Elizabeth enters, carrying a tray with cu of cocoa. They each take a cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Peggy Sue, your mother said you had a dream that I died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish she hadn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid. I know exactly when I'm going to die. Peggy is perplexed by her grandmother's apparent lack of fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it going to be, Elizabeth? SeventyВ—five? Eighty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not telling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been trying to drag it out of her for years. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, dreams are fascinating business. 'Specially where you see the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe in all of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I like to speculate. This book I'm reading right now, a woman in Colorado says she lived in Ireland a hundred and fifty years ago. Her name was Bridey Murphy- and she gives names and dates and where she lived. She was hypnotized. Big bestseller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember that book! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa, Grandma, I want to tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Elizabeth are making strudel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you believe it, darling, then I believe. Being young can be just as confusing as being old. The things that happened to me fifty years ago are more on my mind than what happened yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm remembering the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now you're just browsing through time. Choose the things you'll be proud of. The things that Last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My children make me happy. I miss them so much. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth. Scott and Beth. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to name my daughter after you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy and Barney are washing the car at a standpipe, two hundred feet from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gonna rain again. Every time I wash the car, it rains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That never changes. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, when you and Grandma are gone, the family's gone. I never see the cousins anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your grandma's strudel that's kept this family together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa, if you had a chance to do it all again, what would you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jawing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd take better care of my teeth.
